citation.article-title: Syntrophobacter sulfatireducens sp. nov., a novel syntrophic, propionate-oxidizing bacterium isolated from UASB reactors
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Emended description of the genus Syntrophobacter
The description is based on the phenotypic data of Boone & Bryant (1980), Wallrabenstein et al. (1994, 1995) and Harmsen et al. (1998).
Gram-negative, non-motile, rod- to egg-shaped cells.
Growth by fermentation or by reduction of sulfate to sulfide.
Pure cultures oxidize propionate with sulfate as the electron acceptor.
Propionate is fermented syntrophically to acetate and CO2 in the presence of hydrogen- and/or formate-utilizing methanogens (e.g. Methanospirillum hungatei).
The G+C content of the genomic DNA is 56·7–60·6 mol%.
The type species is Syntrophobacter wolinii.
